Elementary:
In summer, in the Arctic regions of Canada, the
sun shines for more than 20 hours a day. Some
people enjoy this after the constant darkness of
winter. But, for the small Muslim community of
Iqaluit, life in the land of the midnight sun is a real
challenge during the month of Ramadan, when
Muslims fast from sunrise to sunset.

Elementary:
“I haven’t fainted once,” said 29-year-old Abdul
Karim, one of only a few Muslims in the area
who has carefully timed his Ramadan fast to the
Arctic sun. This year, that means he eats at about
1.30am before the sun rises and breaks his fast
at about 11pm when the sun sets. “I would only
stop if it hurt my health,” Karim said.

Elementary:
Most Muslims in Iqaluit follow the timetable that
Muslims in Ottawa, about 1,300 miles south,
follow. This follows the advice of Muslim scholars
who have said Muslims in the far north should
observe Ramadan using the timetable of Mecca
or the nearest Muslim city. They still have to fast
for around 18 hours a day, said Atif Jilani, who
moved to Iqaluit from Toronto. “The days are
long, but we can do it.”

communities in the Arctic, the long days have
forced a change in how they fast.

Elementary:
It’s a similar situation in all of Canada’s most
northern mosques during Ramadan, where
Muslims have to live with very long or very short
days. In recent years, much of the community
has chosen to follow the Ramadan timetable of
Edmonton, in Alberta. Some follow the timetable
of Mecca, for example Awan, a father of two
young children, including a 12-year-old who
recently started fasting. He hopes that the easier
timetable will encourage his son – it means
about 15 hours of fasting, not 18 hours like in
Edmonton. “If I fast Edmonton times, my son
might say, ‘Papa, you are really insane. What are
you doing?’” he said.

Elementary:
For the 100 Muslims in Inuvik, a small town 125
miles north of the Arctic Circle, it is impossible to
follow the local movements of the sun. They also
follow Edmonton’s timetable. “We currently have
24 hours a day of sun,” said Ahmad Alkhalaf.
“There’s no sunrise or sunset.” People already
followed the Edmonton timetable in 2001 when
he moved from Toronto to the small northern
town of 3,500 people. “My first Ramadan here
was in December. There’s no sun at that time; it’s
dark all day and night. So we used
Edmonton time.”
Intermediate:
Many in the community of 100 people break their
fast together – they gather in the city’s brand new
mosque for nightly suppers. As they tuck into
traditional food such as dates and goat or lamb
curries, the sun shines brightly through
the windows.
